title: 105_hr4431
content: The "HIV Partner Protection Act" is cited as the short title. It amends the Public Health Service Act to include a section on partner notification for HIV health care services. The "HIV Partner Protection Act" amends the Public Health Service Act to require states to implement partner notification programs for individuals with HIV disease. States must also ensure that health entities report positive HIV test results to the state public health officer. The "HIV Partner Protection Act" mandates partner notification programs for individuals with HIV disease. States must report positive HIV test results to the state public health officer, without disclosing the infected individuals' identities. Counseling and testing for HIV, including information on transmission modes, are provided to partners and infected individuals. The "HIV Partner Protection Act" mandates partner notification programs for individuals with HIV disease, including counseling on transmission modes, therapeutic measures, and referrals for appropriate services. Notifications are provided in person, with no penalties for infected individuals. The "HIV Partner Protection Act" mandates partner notification programs for individuals with HIV disease, including counseling on transmission modes, therapeutic measures, and referrals for appropriate services. Infected individuals are not penalized for choosing not to identify partners or for errors in reporting under the program. The State is not liable for failing to notify partners, and health entities reporting the identity of infected individuals are not civilly liable. The State must demonstrate that insurance laws prohibit insurers from penalizing individuals who undergo HIV testing after exposure. State insurance laws prohibit insurers from penalizing individuals who have been tested for HIV disease. The term 'infected individual' refers to someone with HIV disease, and 'partner' includes spouses, sexual partners, and individuals who share hypodermic needles for drug injection. The text discusses the definition of "infected individual" in relation to HIV disease and includes spouses, sexual partners, and individuals who share hypodermic needles for drug injection. It also mentions the delayed applicability of certain requirements for states without regular legislative sessions in fiscal years 1999 and 2000. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may provide grants to States to assist with the costs of implementing partner notification programs for HIV. $10,000,000 is authorized to be appropriated annually from 2000 to 2004 for this purpose.
